title: @IronStylus: How's Taric going?
body: I didn't see anything about Taric on the champion update that Fruity Sebbles put up, so I was wondering if hes on the backburner or if there is just nothing particularly interesting going on with his development?

replies.body:
Slowly, from the art side at least. We've been working on a few thing that will come before Taric and are deep in production or have high-priority in pre-production for various reasons. Currently, and Scruffy can probably speak better to this, but his new kit looks like it's shaping up nicely. For us on the art side, that's huge. We can have much more narrow of a focus now that we know specific actions a champion will take and how we build the character around those actions. 

Currently Narrative is helping us on high-priority stuff that's in pre-production. They sort of occupy the same area that Concept does because they help formulate the very core of the character. We think that Taric will be a big discussion in the "near future". Sorry that's so ambiguous. 

That said, we have about 30 concepts of Taric from various artists. This however was done in a bit of a vacuum, back when we were moving in a direction that we really hadn't validated properly, a very much straight-forward dude in blue armor and gems. Since then, the casual discussions around him between art, gameplay and narrative aspects are aligning around something with a slightly different flavor than what we had originally anticipated, and that's good. When the official ideation sessions strike up again I think we'll have a good spring board. Narrative helps tremendously in those discussions because we want to understand what made Taric into Taric and what his current pillars of design are.

Likewise, having gameplay in place really helps as well because we're not designing in a vacuum, we're working towards the goals of fulfilling the needs of that gameplay.

> [{quoted}](name=IronStylus,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=gEKAkdFJ,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2015-02-13T07:17:22.483+0000)
>
> Currently Narrative is helping us on high-priority stuff that's in pre-production. They sort of occupy the same area that Concept does because they help formulate the very core of the character. We think that Taric will be a big discussion in the "near future". Sorry that's so ambiguous. 

I think it would be great if Narrative followed your example and held some meaningful discussions on Taric with the community as they decide where they're going with him. It would be a marked change from their current modus operandi, but there have been hints that they're coming around. I've definitely noticed them trying to make new material more backwards-compatible, for instance, and they're at least sort of making token efforts at "what Champions do you want to talk about" threads. I wasn't sure what to make of this.

A major rework of a character like Taric is a fantastic opportunity for Narrative to really make good on these preliminary gestures and have some genuine community discussionâ€”to treat the community not just as a passive audience but as a source of ideas and alternate viewpoints. I mentioned the community discussion threads you did for Taric on the art side. I thought that was a good discussion, and judging from your comments it sounds like you did get some good ideas and feedback from it. (Of course, we also came to better appreciate your ideas. I took particular note of your observation that people were at first too quick to basically make him into one big "fabulous" joke, which was not only unsatisfying but, when you think about it, really kind of demeaning.) It is, as always, our honor to assist our glorious parrot sovereign. I think my contribution was a picture of Richard Gere from First Knight, as a way for him to be "beautiful" while still having a lot of maturity and strength, rather than either going totally bishounen or just making him another big buff dude.

https://mutantreviewers.files.wordpress.com/2011/04/first_knight.jpg
*Magic has ruined this land. Now I will stare soulfully into the distance.*

Isn't that how Riot works? You ask about Taric. You see a bunch of ideas. One of them is my idea for Taric. Maybe you love it, and adopt it. Maybe you hate it, and realizing how much you hate it helps inspire you with a completely opposite concept. Maybe it's just one of many ideas that are appealing in some ways and unappealing in others, and together help you come up with what you really want to see. Whatever the case, I think threads like those are enriching, and help anchor Riot in its community.

I know, I know. I probably misconstrued your post. I shouldn't even be posting; I told myself I'd stop wasting time trying to reach out to Narrative. But I feel so weird about simultaneously liking them and dreading them that I can't help myself. Sometimes, a situation is just so crazy that you can't stop trying to do something about it. And ever since the Great Retcon, I've been like:

http://i.imgur.com/DEfnmbE.gif
*No more League of Legends in League of Legends?*  
*Rioters refusing to talk with their own community?* 
*FELLOW SUMMONERS, HAVE I QUAFFED THE ELIXIR OF MADNESS?*
Have you seen the three big threads I posted about Taric a while ago? That seemed to be a productive conversation.

> [{quoted}](name=IronStylus,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=gEKAkdFJ,comment-id=000200000000,timestamp=2015-02-13T08:00:40.180+0000)
>
> Have you seen the three big threads I posted about Taric a while ago? That seemed to be a productive conversation.

Well, there is a major difference between you (including some people at ChampUp) and Narrative.

You interact with those interested in the champions you're scheduled / planning on reworking.  Gathering fan opinions on how they feel a champion should exist within the game world.  This is awesome and should be encouraged, even if you don't use any of our ideas at all.  

(Sorry if I trundle through this.  I'm trying to get everything out and it's too early in the morning as I type this).

Narrative, on the other hand, doesn't bother trying to do any of that.  They seem to think that they know these champions better than we do and are somehow above community interaction.  In the past three months, the amount of interaction we've seen from Narrative has dwindled down to a handful of posts along with one pinned thread where they also say they can't read story suggestions for "legal" reasons.   That last one was a full week ago.  When some of us asked about an explanation for these "legal reasons," they went back into their silent mode.  So much for "we want to communicate," eh?

In other words, Parrot, you are an example of how a developer should talk with their fans... Narrative is the one department within Riot that shits on the "we're all about our community" ideals, intentionally or not.

So, when you post...

> Currently Narrative is helping us on high-priority stuff that's in pre-production. They sort of occupy the same area that Concept does because they help formulate the very core of the character. We think that Taric will be a big discussion in the "near future". Sorry that's so ambiguous. 

..that doesn't bode well for us lore fans who would have loved an opportunity to have a discussion about Taric before anything was set in concrete.  Jaredan keeps *saying* that he wants to communicate with us more, but I'm just not seeing any effort directed towards that and don't really think he has any desire to so.

I'm sorry that I've had to bring this up in this thread, Parrot, but Narrative just isn't listening to us (once again) and we're desperate for attention.

It's not as clear cut as that.  You're talking about a discipline versus a team.

You want a specific conversation on a broad subject base with a discipline, one that's spread across 3 content teams and then some. That's pretty much the same thing as "The concept team doesn't interact with us and we want a stake in how concepts are developed, so Concept team, come tell us what's up, put your cards on the table." Well, Concept is spread across 3 content teams and then some also. You wouldn't get much consensus nor would anything be able to be directly communicated from a central source.

Narrative doesn't flow from some high waterfall for the content teams to lap up in the pond. It's a discipline matrixed into various teams, Champion, ChampUP, Events, etc. Yes, there are some teams, such as the team Ant is on which create some foundational pillars for the IP in-game and beyond, but that information, even coming from the foundations aspect isn't a handed-down writ. Each content team is using Narrative as a resource to be allocated and to utilize as a service of sorts, not treat it as a central spigot source of lore. Narrative doesn't operate in a black box, we work directly with them and in a pretty meaningful way, especially on ChampUP. We're really the only content team that can funnel refreshed and updated characters into the game experience and therefore become canon. But they're not handing out some sort of doctrine, we're conversing back and forth.

So, when you're asking to be involved, and here I come asking about Taric, there's your chance! I'm taking feedback not just on art, but on themes, tropes, stories and more. I represent a team you're going to get a product from and I can speak from that standpoint and possibly, depending on circumstance, where directionally Narrative is helping us move. This very board is for Story and Art for a reason. They're very intertwined. 

Will I be able to say everything? Heck no. But that's not anything new. I can talk about what we're exploring, just like how Gameplay can tell you about how a kit is coming along or about future plans to adjust balance. I can talk to you in the same way that any sort of pre-production person can. 

> Narrative, on the other hand, doesn't bother trying to do any of that. They seem to think that they know these champions better than we do and are somehow above community interaction. 

This actually really bugs me. Do you know who's ultimately responsible for updated content going out? ChampUP. We also coordinate with Events and other departments on projects such the Freljord and Shurima events. Indeed, there might be things filled in here and there by Narrative as a discipline, large scale sequential story-telling, or general updates on IP building and world creation, but our team is the one handing  you the new thing that's replacing the old thing. If you're going to accuse anyone of disregarding your sentiments, then go ahead and accuse me if you'd really like to place blame. I'm part of the team that is indeed changing champions which sometimes creates friction with the community. But even that is a decision made by the content team that's putting out the work, not some sort of voice from the clouds telling us what to do. 

Myself, I do come to the community to gather information and seek feedback. If you'd like to direct the questions my way, I'm happy to answer where I can, in the context of what content my team produces. I'm not sure that'll scratch your itch, but I'm glad to offer what I can. I'm also more than happy to hear ideas since I interface with Narrative and can deliver feedback that you might give. Please, use the tools in front of you. 

I'm never going to drag someone "kicking and screaming" in here, that's not the answer, and that would be pretty rude of me to assume I can do their job better than they can. At Riot we have the sentiment of deferring to trust. We trust that team members and other teams will do the right thing. We trust that they'll do good by the work they sign up for. We trust that they're able craftsmen. I trust that about Narrative because I work with them. They're some of the smartest, level-headed people I know who care for depth and breadth in story. I'm a lover of story myself and prefer to develop characters that have a compelling core. It's exhilarating working with them. And yes, it is a dialogue. 

I won't be able to divulge everything, but I can certainly tell you that the things the community talks about are resonant in that department and make it into the feedback loop. When ChampUP in particular is working on a project we're heavily invested into what the player perception is and how we can preserve yet enhance it. They're in the same frame of mind, but damn, do they have a task in front of them. I don't envy them. But what can I do? I can help them by offering our team as an extension of updates they want to introduce. I can work with them to deliver feedback and jam on ideas. 

The perfect balance has yet to be achieved, but it's happening. We had a great meeting today about some future content we're making and it has us all super excited. Every step of the way we've worked with Narrative and it's been a stellar experience. 

I would urge you to default to trust, but I understand your position, the history you've witnessed and the feeling of being left out. 

In any case, I'm always up to hear ideas, field questions where I can and generally be of help when possible.

Thank you, Parrot.  Rest assured, I read the whole thing, but I wanted to focus on a few parts of this.

It seems that when it comes to Narrative, however, they just release things (*Freljord, Retcon*), make false apologies (*we're sorry we didn't say anything*), make promises to change (*we will start communicating more*) then completely ignore their vows (months or years of silence).

So, when we see Jaredan and some of the people on Narrative spend more time on Twitter talking up their weekly Dungeons and Dragons game than they would ever consider using to interact with their fans, it's beyond frustrating.

Well, your threads on Taric mostly focused on acquiring Art resources and suggestions.  That's obvious given your chosen discipline.  If I recall correctly, however, there wasn't a "where do you see Taric's story" part in your suggestions threads.  Had I known you wanted story suggestions as well as art references, I would have gladly provided them.  I'm just afraid that even in this early point in the process, any suggestions I have may be a case of "too little, too late."
 
> This actually really bugs me. Do you know who's ultimately responsible for updated content going out? ChampUP. We also coordinate with Events and other departments on projects such the Freljord and Shurima events. Indeed, there might be things filled in here and there by Narrative as a discipline, large scale sequential story-telling, or general updates on IP building and world creation, but our team is the one handing  you the new thing that's replacing the old thing. 

So... your team is responsible for the decision to remove the Institute of War and the impact of Summoners on the story world?  Is your team the reason why the new updated bios haven't been delivered as promised?  Does ChampUp tell Narrative to tie in every new story to a champ release or rework and also why Singed's back story has remained broken for almost two and a half years?

ChampUp is the reason why Narrative keeps repeating this cycle of making big promises then breaking them and treating us with silence?  Is this what you're telling us?  I don't think you want to be responsible for all that.

>If you're going to accuse anyone of disregarding your sentiments, then go ahead and accuse me if you'd really like to place blame. I'm part of the team that is indeed changing champions which sometimes creates friction with the community. But even that is a decision made by the content team that's putting out the work, not some sort of voice from the clouds telling us what to do. 

Someone or something is responsible for Narrative's cycle of sudden reveals, apologies, big promises and silence.  If it's you and your team, please stop it.  If not, then there should be some sort of way to discuss the whys and how to fix them and get them interacting with us.  
 
> Myself, I do come to the community to gather information and seek feedback. If you'd like to direct the questions my way, I'm happy to answer where I can, in the context of what content my team produces. I'm not sure that'll scratch your itch, but I'm glad to offer what I can. I'm also more than happy to hear ideas since I interface with Narrative and can deliver feedback that you might give. Please, use the tools in front of you. 

All due respect, Parrot, but if Riot Games *wanted* community advocates to talk to the various teams about certain concerns, they'd have them already in place.  It's so frustrating and infuriating that we would need to have non-Narrative Rioters like yourself, Riot Sweet and so many others have to come in and ping people from Narrative when they should be doing that on their own.

Instead, we're getting mostly silence from Narrative.  Silence and warnings to not offer story and character suggestions for undisclosed or unspecified "legal reasons."
 
> I'm never going to drag someone "kicking and screaming" in here, that's not the answer, and that would be pretty rude of me to assume I can do their job better than they can. At Riot we have the sentiment of deferring to trust. We trust that team members and other teams will do the right thing. We trust that they'll do good by the work they sign up for. We trust that they're able craftsmen. I trust that about Narrative because I work with them. They're some of the smartest, level-headed people I know who care for depth and breadth in story. I'm a lover of story myself and prefer to develop characters that have a compelling core. It's exhilarating working with them. And yes, it is a dialogue. 

That's nice that you trust the people at Narrative and that your trust is being rewarded by seeing them do the work they promise to put out.  They give you a reason to trust them and to continue to trust them.

I *don't* trust them because they keep making promises and breaking them.  From the removal of the Journals of Justice to the Freljord disasters to the Retcon announcement ***after a year and a half of silence*** to this latest period with Jaredan and Ant, the cycle of making and breaking promises continues.

Additionally, Narrative *won't* give me a reason to trust them even though they keep asking for my trust.  Also, since **my** trust in them isn't necessary for them to do their job, there's no real reason why they would even bother trying to earn it, Riot Games policies or not.
 
> I won't be able to divulge everything, but I can certainly tell you that the things the community talks about are resonant in that department and make it into the feedback loop. When ChampUP in particular is working on a project we're heavily invested into what the player perception is and how we can preserve yet enhance it. They're in the same frame of mind, but damn, do they have a task in front of them. I don't envy them. But what can I do? I can help them by offering our team as an extension of updates they want to introduce. I can work with them to deliver feedback and jam on ideas. 

If there was evidence of this, I'd love to see it.  Instead, we get Ant telling us not to offer story ideas because "we can't use them... *for legal reasons*."  Then, when the team is asked "why," they turtle back into silent mode.

> The perfect balance has yet to be achieved, but it's happening. We had a great meeting today about some future content we're making and it has us all super excited. Every step of the way we've worked with Narrative and it's been a stellar experience. 

How nice.  :/  More upcoming content that was discussed *without* fan interaction.  I'm glad you're having a wonderful time with Narrative, but this sort of thing is **exactly** why our frustration grows.

Just about every other department at Riot Games, from Game Balance to Skins, has some example of how fan interaction shaped a piece of content *before* it was released.  Narrative, however, does not and I've been a League lore fan for over three years.  I don't know why this is but it just adds sadness to my "emotion salad" concerning Narrative.
 
> I would urge you to default to trust, but I understand your position, the history you've witnessed and the feeling of being left out.

Trust?  To quote Inigo Montoya.  *"You keep using that word. I do not think it means what you think it means."*

It's not a "feeling" of being left out.  We **have** been left out of the conversation.  With one exception (Udyr and Ionia), where was fan input and ideas addressed with the removal of the Journal of Justice, League Judgement and the Freljord changes?  Where were fan ideas collected and addressed before the Retcon announcement last September?  

Give me a reason to trust you and, maybe, I will.  I'll go out on a limb and suggest most Lore fans would agree with that sentiment.
 
> In any case, I'm always up to hear ideas, field questions where I can and generally be of help when possible.

Suggestion, then:  Start a new thread asking "What should Taric's story be?," let it stew for a week on the boards, then send the suggestions over to Narrative and Foundations for their opinions.  That is, if "legal reasons" won't stop them from doing so.

Frankly, that's how it should be for every champion, but we're talking about Taric here.

If you want to talk sometime in client we can do that. I'll add you, keep a lookout. I unfortunately don't have a ton of time to reply in long format.

I will say this though, there is no feasible way we can make, maintain and keep diligent over a thread for every updated champion requesting story submissions. That's just way beyond our team's capability. 

We wouldn't have the logistical ability to give it proper attention especially with how our pipeline operates. And as I've said before that option would be weighted heavily towards western feedback which isn't fair to our players in the east. Additionally the concerns that Ant expresses are real. It's why I prefer reference rather than user generated concepts for updates.

I don't know about anyone else, but I don't want a story submission inbox. I just want, whenever Riot is planning on making changes to an established character/faction/story/whatever, to come to us and say 'we're thinking of making changes to this thing. What about this thing are you really into (so we know that this is important and we shouldn't touch it) and which things do you not like (so we can improve upon it)'.

Cause a bunch of the complaints I'm seeing, and several of my own, come from Riot either not understanding or not caring about what we like from a champion. For example, I believe several Rioters commented after the backlash from the Karma changes that they didn't know that the community liked her fans so much.

We're not exactly sure about the difference here. I mean, does that mean we shouldn't be coming up with specific champions over at the Skins and Champions Concept section? Do we have to be more broad such as "Armored wrestling woman" or "Dancing champion"?

No, but that is why people like Kateykhaos put it into a folder of ideas and not bookmark them, also they specifically mention it in their EULA that skins and champions can be taken modified in any way shape or form and no credit will be given.
So then what's the difference between that and us giving narrative story ideas?

Not sure, from the way the EULA and Terms of Service word everything they should not have a problem with us posting ideas, so really the only thing is they don't want to deal with any idiots who try to claim ownership of a story or character within the game, because unless they do not have an account of League of Legends and are simply creating their derivative work entirely through information from League wiki, they have signed the contracts and Riot is free to do as they please. So perhaps if there was a way to post the fanfictions entirely on the boards they would be fine with it.

PS: Not a lawyer or planning to go to Law School so don't quote me on this please.

First off: I know this might be sounding eerie at this point (I swear I'm not going to come wandering out of your bushes with parrot-shaped cookies and a deranged smile on my face), but I really like you, IronStylus. You're on the community short-list of Great Rioters for a reason. You're talented and creative, and you also have a certain honesty about you that is reallyâ€¦old-school? You don't make us feel like we're being "handled" by a corporate behemoth. I'm not really in a position to talk about the "good old days", as I didn't join until 2010 or so, but I think you really *get* what makes Riot unusual, particularly in the community department. (Okay, end eerie profession of affection.) You seem slightly defensive at times here, and I want to reassure youâ€”you may not realize just how deep a well of trust you have with the community. I for one am not for a second doubting your sincerity or motivations, so please, don't understand anything I say as an implied attack on you.

---

Thank you for this post. That actually does make things a lot clearer. I do recall Narrative making references to being linked to other departments, but I didn't really get the big picture until I read your comment here, specifically, that "ChampUP" is a sort of task force that sits above (and draws from) various departments.

It certainly wasn't meant as a sign of disrespect toward you. I just honestly didn't realize that Taric's lore changes would be managed not by Narrative so much as by ChampUP. If I understand you rightly, as a member of the ChampUP task force, you're actually in a position to say, e.g., "Hey Narrative, can you draft me an alternate story that has Taric coming from Demacia? And maybe one where he's coming from Ionia? I'd like to see how those look." That's kind of an awkward example, but I hope it illustrates the pointâ€”that Narrative is not locked away in some weird black box.

To be honest, I guess to some extent I was assuming that Narrative's relationship with other Rioters was comparable to its relationship with the communityâ€”a frustratingly one-way and non-interactive process by which lore is "handed down from on high".

> Will I be able to say everything? Heck no. But that's not anything new. I can talk about what we're exploring, just like how Gameplay can tell you about how a kit is coming along or about future plans to adjust balance. I can talk to you in the same way that any sort of pre-production person can.

This is basically what we've been asking for. We are not, repeat **not**, asking to have this put to a vote. That would be crazy for many reasons, not least that we represent a small (though I believe uncommonly invested) fraction of the playerbase, and because I've tried design-by-democracy myself in some of my personal projects, and it failed miserably. (By "design-by-democracy", I mean specifically putting every. last. thing. to a vote. It made me painfully aware of the importance of some executive force that can discuss and collaborate, but also at the end of the day make a decision that has some continuity with the overall vision.) What we're asking for is what Riot does in many other areas, and what you've done with Taric (mostly on art, but I think there was some story discussion there, too) and others.

What I'm asking for is really just what you describe. That at certain times in the development process, you come by, share some of the ideas you're exploring (especially those that would radically contradict established lore/themeâ€”which is not a bad thing, but is a potentially dangerous thing), and discuss with the community, using us as a sort of focus group. I really enjoyed that discussion on Taric, for example: what's his core identity? Is he an angry smiter-paladin? Is he a healer who doesn't really need to be carrying a weapon in the first place? Is he a protector? Is he morose, or just quiet? Those questions are ultimately yours to answer, but I think that we often have some things to say that are worth listening to, and even when we don't, I get the impression that sometimes batting ideas around with us helps your own creative thinking. And, on the "negative" side, it does sometimes serve an important "emergency brake" function, when you don't realize just how unhappy we'd be with a particular change. ("Whoa, we didn't realize that people actually LIKED that part of the character.") Not that we have a veto, but I think, yeah, sometimes it's important to do a sweep and see if anything jumps out as extremely objectionable. In such cases, maybe it can be trivially changed. Maybe the problem is that we don't get it, and it can be explained, or clarified. Or maybe we do get it, and we just sharply disagree, and then it's up to you to make that decision while aware of the disagreement. Unpopular changes can be great changes. But I think it's good to at least hear the opposition out first.
Glad I could be of help. If you want to talk about it further I added you in-game a while back but haven't seen you on.

The point is that there's a clear difference between you being outspoken with feedback, while the narrative team being silent. Even if you all work on the same thing, it's a PR issue. Was there discussion on Cassiopeia's ties to Noxus, because it's barely referenced as we're waiting for her story. Was there discussion on changing the characters of Karma, Xerath, or Trundle? One of them was a recent change after making a statement in the past about not dramatically retconning a character. IIRC. I'm sure we can blame you for things along with your team. You're not perfect. However as people have said, we're more than willing to give you the benefit of the doubt because your team has earned it with good relations and work.

***
Why Trundle is different in short (feel free to skip this if you already know):

Old Trundle would've tried to aid his tribe, venture for the weapon and come back, expecting to be hailed as a hero. He'd then probably find out his tribe is just a bunch of, well, unpleasant selfish trolls. However, without institute, he'd have nowhere to go. If he left, he'd just be killed by some humans. He becomes the cynical troll I know.

The new Trundle however, goes back to his tribe, is hailed as a hero and becomes powerhungry rather than cynical. Now his new VO oozes this powerhunger in about a third of his lines. It's one of his main traits, next to violent and sadistic (common troll traits). 

He also isn't represented as a runt. He loses to the old chieftain, but the first line of his lore already describes him as a hulking troll and we have no other trolls to compare him to. This seems quite a change from the leprous runt.

***

It just looks to me Riot tried to keep his character intact at first, but then just gave up and made a new troll instead. This could happen to anyone. 
Is Skarner going to be a ferocious beast? Is Veigar no longer going to be an mad evil yordle with noble goals? Will Teemo no longer be a cold-hearted killer putting on a happy mask? Will Cho'Gath no longer be an intelligent monster?

I'd like to enjoy the lore, but if characters can just be discarded like that, why should I care about these characters? I don't want to feel like I did when I saw the new Trundle again. I didn't play Trundle for a month after and I wouldn't play him at all hadn't I still had his old and limited VO.

Worst thing is, there might be fans of the new troll. It's been so long I can't reasonably ask you to remove the new troll in favor of Trundle because that'd be removing *another* character.

***

So can I ask you about the removal of characters in favor of others, Ironstylus? Can I ask you why one of my favorite characters was just removed and replaced? Can I ask you if you are ok with me fearing for my other favorites? Can I ask you if I'm being unreasonable here?

Can I ask you if I will ever be able to just carelessly enjoy Leagues lore again?
